w21z719ghd.name: Jamae Chulia Mosque
w21z719ghd.remarks: The masjid was a contribution by the Chulian community. Built in 1826, it has gone through several places of renovation and expansion. The building bears the imprint of South Indian architecture in its narrow frontages, which are defined by minaret-style towers. Located in the Central part of the island, it serves office workers and has a capacity of 1500 people. It is one of the few masjids in Singapore, which organizes religious classes in Tamil.

w21z75mxh0.name: Burhani Mosque
w21z75mxh0.remarks: Sandwiched between high-rise buildings, this old generation masjid was established by the Dawoodi Bohra community in Singapore as early as 1829. Conveniently located in the Central district, it can accommodate up to 150 people. It is also frequented by office workers in the Hill Street and High Street areas.

w21z77s647.directions: Take lift from main lobby to Basement 1 and turn right. Enter exit door (to carpark B1) and turn right towards carpark. Turn left and there is a small prayer place located at the extreme end.
w21z77s647.name: Suntec City/Millenia Walk
w21z77s647.remarks: Ablution place is provided outside the room

w21z7ndgnk.directions: Women's Wing, at the staircase landing beside 24hr clinic (behind Exit door).
w21z7ndgnk.name: KK Women's and Children's Hospital

w21z74vu88.directions: Enter straircase 2 located beside unit #03-09. Enter another door (any one). Musolla is located under the staircase.
w21z74vu88.name: Adelphi
w21z74vu88.remarks: Shared male and female praying area.

w21z7ht9vs.name: Bencoolen Mosque
w21z7ht9vs.remarks: This masjid was originally built in 1845. In 2001, the mosque's site was redeveloped as part of a mixed development comprising of a commercial block and a 12-storey residential complex. The redeveloped masjid, which is part of the complex, was opened to the public in May 2004. It can accommodate about 1,100 worshippers.

w21z743n5q.name: Omar Kg Melaka Mosque
w21z743n5q.remarks: The oldest masjid in Singapore, it has humble beginnings as a wooden surau way back in 1820. Monetary contributions from wealthy merchant Syed Abdullah bin Omar Aljunied made possible its rebuilding in 1855. The old generation masjid located in the Central, underwent yet another major rebuilding project several years ago in which a tall minaret with a small roof dome is added at the entrance of the mosque. With a capacity of 500 people, it is the focal point for office workers during daily and Friday prayers

w21z7mntqm.name: Hajjah Fatimah Mosque
w21z7mntqm.remarks: This is another old generation masjid built from donation from a wealthy lady named Fatimah. Located in the Central district, it was completed in 1846. the masjid bears the imprint of colonial architect J T Thomson, is a charming blend of local and European architecture. It is today one of Singapore’s national monuments. Extensive renovation work was carried out several years ago in which its leaning minaret was righted. The masjid, which can accommodate up to 600 people offers religious lectures on an ad-hoc basis. It is particularly popular among office workers in Jalan Sultan area

w21z75x6cc.directions: Beside Quest Salon #02-27. Go straight between WAREHOUSE and BCBGMAXAZRIA.
w21z75x6cc.name: Raffles City Shopping Centre
w21z75x6cc.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Slippers, Tasbih, Al-Quran, Sarong, Songkok, Telekung
w21z75x6cc.remarks: Segregated male and female praying area. Can also be accessed from Swissotel The Stamford Hotel.

w21z7ms6tv.name: Malabar Mosque
w21z7ms6tv.remarks: One can hardly miss this blue-tiled building adorned with gold-coloured domes located at the junction of Victoria Street and Jalan Sultan. This redeveloped masjid was first built in 1918. in 1962, it underwent major rebuilding into what it is today. Located in the Central part of the island, it serves the needs of office workers around the area and has a capacity of 1000 people. Besides religious classes, it organizes zikir sessions.

w21z7hc8wk.directions: Enter the EXIT door at lift lobby level 5. Lift lobby is located between Seahorse and V.Hive.
w21z7hc8wk.name: Plaza Singapura
w21z7hc8wk.remarks: Not an official praying area. Shared male & female area. Provision found in the hosereel cabinet.

w21z7tjzt5.directions: From NTUC xtra, walk towards the toilet beside it. The location is at the fire exit before the toilet.
w21z7tjzt5.name: Kallang Wave Mall
w21z7tjzt5.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Slippers Provided For.
w21z7tjzt5.remarks: The area is a long corridor, so if you bring your own prayer mat, you can pray there too.

images.caption: One Long Stretch Of Solah Area

w21z7hc9v7.directions:
Located at staircase near lift, end of Spotlight outlet. Adjacent to the home furnishing section of Spotlight outlet. There's a room in between the staircase and the lifts.

Room is not entitled for prayers. However, prayers are allowed.

Wudu' to be taken at the washroom beside it.
w21z7hc9v7.name: Plaza Singapura
w21z7hc9v7.remarks: Bring own sejadah/praying mat. And telekung (for muslimah)

w21z7ph8nn.name: Tasek Utara Mosque
w21z7ph8nn.remarks: In sharp contrast to a Saracenic style masjid or avant-garde looking religious structures, this old generation masjid is simple yet functional. Located at the junction of Bristol Road and Carlisle Road, this one-storey masjid can accommodate up to 120 people. Built in 1907 its main activities include daily and Friday prayers as well as occasional religious lectures.

w21z7pbs29.directions: From the lift, walk straight towards the white generators. Once in front, turn right
w21z7pbs29.name: United Square
w21z7pbs29.provision: Prayer Mat, Slippers, Al-Qur'an, Sarong, Telekung, Chair
w21z7pbs29.remarks: Shared male and female praying area. Nearest lift to musolla is located beside Efflorescence shop on level 1.

w21z790z4d.directions: Beside Texas Chicken at the Supreme Dining Area. Look for a small room (white door) which states 'Musholla'.
w21z790z4d.name: Gardens by the Bay

w21z774g4w.directions: Go down the escalator beside QiJi to basement. Out the glass door, turn left and left again. Head to the extreme left of the carpark. Musolla is located near carpark ramp.
w21z774g4w.name: Marina Square
w21z774g4w.provision: Prayer Mat, Chair, Sarong, Tasbih, Songkok, Al-Quran, Telekung, Fan
w21z774g4w.remarks: There is an ablution area near the musolla. Shared male and female praying area.

w21z7jryeg.name: Abdul Gafoor Mosque
w21z7jryeg.remarks: Originally built in 1859, this masjid with its unique architecture has earned the distinction as  one of Singapore's national monuments. It has an unabashed mélange of styles – a mix of Southern Indian, Moghul and Europeans influences.  Located in the Central part of Singapore, it has since been redeveloped (re-opened in 1998) with a capacity of 3000 and offers madrasah classes in Tamil besides its usual religious classes.

w21z7zpx3z.name: Khadijah Mosque
w21z7zpx3z.remarks: Built in 1920, the masjid is currently being restored to its original splendour. Named after the wealthy lady who donated $50000 in 1916 to build this masjid, restoration works was completed in 2001. The masjid located in the Central part of Singapore has a current capacity of 500 people. Its activities include computer classes, training and youth programmes as well as tuition.

w21z7m5crz.name: Sultan Mosque
w21z7m5crz.remarks: Built during colonial times, this old generation masjid has been gazetted as a national monument. Built in 1824, it was one of the first few masjids to be built on the island. It was later rebuilt in 1920 by Swan and Maclaren who were responsible for Singapore’s other important landmarks. The masjid is a mix of Classical, Persian, Moorish and Turkish themes that form what is known as the Islamic Saracenic style. Located in the Central, it has a capacity of 2000 people and is one of the most frequented prayer venue.

w21z71531b.name: Al-Abrar Mosque
w21z71531b.remarks: The masjid, which bears the imprint of South Indian architecture in its narrow frontages, which are defined by two minaret-style towers, was founded in 1827. But it was only in 1855, that a formal building was set up. In 1974, the old generation masjid located in Central Singapore was gazetted as one of the national monuments. With a capacity of 500, it serves the needs of office workers in the Shenton Road area. Unlike neighbourhood masjids, which spring to life in the evening, this masjid is relatively quiet except for its occasional Tafsir Al-Quran (Al-Quran interpretation) courses.

w21z7q83hz.name: Angullia Mosque
w21z7q83hz.remarks: If there is one masjid, which attracts a wide range of nationalities, it must be the Masjid Angullia. Located along one of Singapore’s busiest main roads in the Central district, the mosque is a place for devotion of shoppers across the road at Serangoon Plaza as well as shopkeepers and office workers nearby. It can accommodate 400 Muslims any one time. Built with funds from a wealthy Angullia family in 1970, it has an Indian-like minaret. Today, it is famous as a center of tabligh (activities to promote Islam).

w21z7ybu59.name: Haji Mohd Salleh (G) Mosque
w21z7ybu59.remarks: A historic milestone was achieved in November 1999 when its new four-storey building was officially opened after more than a year of extensive rebuilding. The original structure which dated back in 1896 was built on land donated by an individual. The masjid with its simple and modern architecture can accommodate up to 1,500 congregants.
